prefix: Approach the following question the way someone in elementary school would.
problem_prompt:
Approach the following question the way someone in elementary school would. At the Gooddog Obedience School, dogs can learn to do three tricks: sit, stay, and roll over. Of the dogs at the school: \begin{tabular}{l@{\qquad}l}
50 dogs can sit & 17 dogs can sit and stay \\
29 dogs can stay & 12 dogs can stay and roll over \\
34 dogs can roll over & 18 dogs can sit and roll over \\
9 dogs can do all three & 9 dogs can do none
\end{tabular} How many dogs are in the school?
gpt_response:
Let's start by listing out what we know:
- 50 dogs can sit
- 29 dogs can stay
- 34 dogs can roll over
- 17 dogs can sit and stay
- 12 dogs can stay and roll over
- 18 dogs can sit and roll over
- 9 dogs can do all three
- 9 dogs can do none

Now let's figure out how many dogs can do each individual trick:
- Sit only: 50 - 17 (sit and stay) - 18 (sit and roll over) + 9 (all three) = 24
- Stay only: 29 - 17 (sit and stay) - 12 (stay and roll over) + 9 (all three) = 9
- Roll over only: 34 - 12 (stay and roll over) - 18 (sit and roll over) + 9 (all three) = 13

Now we add up all the dogs that can do each trick:
24 (sit only) + 9 (stay only) + 13 (roll over only) + 17 (sit and stay) + 12 (stay and roll over) + 18 (sit and roll over) + 9 (all three) + 9 (none) = 111

So there are 111 dogs at the Gooddog Obedience School.
solution_prompt:
Yes or no, is the final solution obtained in the following equal to 84?: Let's start by listing out what we know:
- 50 dogs can sit
- 29 dogs can stay
- 34 dogs can roll over
- 17 dogs can sit and stay
- 12 dogs can stay and roll over
- 18 dogs can sit and roll over
- 9 dogs can do all three
- 9 dogs can do none

Now let's figure out how many dogs can do each individual trick:
- Sit only: 50 - 17 (sit and stay) - 18 (sit and roll over) + 9 (all three) = 24
- Stay only: 29 - 17 (sit and stay) - 12 (stay and roll over) + 9 (all three) = 9
- Roll over only: 34 - 12 (stay and roll over) - 18 (sit and roll over) + 9 (all three) = 13

Now we add up all the dogs that can do each trick:
24 (sit only) + 9 (stay only) + 13 (roll over only) + 17 (sit and stay) + 12 (stay and roll over) + 18 (sit and roll over) + 9 (all three) + 9 (none) = 111

So there are 111 dogs at the Gooddog Obedience School.
gpt_response_correct_incorrect: No, the final solution obtained is 111, not 84.
